TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Coarse-loamy, mixed, superactive Cumulic Cryaquolls

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Dobrow loam - grassland.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
01--3 to 2 inches; grass remains, roots, and leaves.
02--2 to 0 inch; partially decomposed organic materials like that of the horizon above.
A11g--0 to 4 inches; dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) loam, very dark brown (10YR 2/2) moist; strong fine granular and crumb structure; soft, very friable, slightly sticky, slightly plastic; common medium distinct mottles, dark reddish brown (5YR 3/4) and yellowish brown (10YR 5/8) moist; mildly alkaline (pH 7.6); clear smooth boundary.  (3 to 6 inches thick)
A12g--4 to 10 inches; dark gray (10YR 4/1) sandy loam, very dark gray (10YR 3/1) moist; weak coarse subangular blocky structure that parts to fine granules; slightly hard, very friable, nonsticky, nonplastic; common medium prominent mottles, dark reddish brown (5YR 3/4) and yellowish brown (10YR 5/8) moist; neutral (pH 7.0); clear smooth boundary.  (4 to 12 inches thick)
A13g--10 to 28 inches; gray (10YR 5/1) fine sandy loam, dark gray (10YR 3/1) moist; weak coarse subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, very friable, nonsticky, nonplastic; common medium prominent mottles, reddish brown (5YR 3/4) and yellowish brown (10YR 5/8) moist; neutral (pH 7.0); clear smooth boundary.  (14 to 33 inches thick)
IICg--28 to 60 inches; light brownish gray (10YR 6/2) very gravelly sand, grayish brown (10YR 5/2) moist; single grained; loose; common medium distinct dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) and yellowish brown (10YR 5/8) moist mottles; 60 percent gravel; neutral (pH 7.2).

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Jackson County, Colorado; near center of Sec. 5, T. 9 N., R. 79 W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:   Mean annual soil temperature is about 42 degrees F. and mean summer soil temperature is about 56 degrees F.  The mollic epipedon ranges from 21 to 40 inches thick.  Usually the mollic epipedon rests directly on the sandy-skeletal substratum, but mottled B2 horizons of low chroma occur below the mollic epipedon in some pedons.  O horizons are usually present but are thin.  The soil is 60 to 100 percent base saturated.  Depth to the noncontrasting IIC horizon ranges from 26 to 40 inches.  Texture of the control section is typically a sandy loam averages 5 to 18 percent clay, 5 to 40 percent silt, and 50 to 82 percent sand with more than 35 percent fine or coarser sand.  Rock fragments range from 0 to 35 percent in a major part of the control section above the IIC horizon and are mainly 1/4 to 10 inches in diameter.
The A horizon has hue of 5Y through 7.5YR, value of 4 or 5 dry, 2 or 3 moist, and chroma of 1 or 2 and has common distinct to many prominent mottles.  It ranges from slightly acid to mildly alkaline.
The B2 horizon, if present, has hue of 5Y through 7.5YR, value of 5 through 7 dry, 4 through 6 moist, and chroma of neutral through 2, and has common distinct to many prominent mottles.  It ranges from slightly acid to mildly alkaline.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Fleer, Mendenhall, New Fork, and Tepee series.  Fleer soils are calcareous above a depth of 10 inches.  Mendenhall soils are calcareous in all parts between depths of 10 and 20 inches.  New Fork soils have a mollic epipedon less than 20 inches thick.  Tepee soils have a fine-loamy control section.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  These soils are usually on flood plains.  Slopes typically range from 0 to about 6 percent.  The soils formed in moderately coarse textured alluvial sediments overlying sand and gravel beds.  At the type location these soils occur at elevations of 8,000 feet or higher.  Average annual precipitation is approximately 10 inches with peak periods of precipitation during the spring and early summer.  The average annual temperature is 36 degrees F and the mean temperature is 56 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the competing Fleer soils and the Wichup soils.  Wichup soils have a histic epipedon.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Poorly to very poorly drained; slow  runoff to ponded; rapid permeability.  These soils have high water tables that occur at or near the surface most of the year.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  These soils are used as native pastureland or for native hay meadow.  Principal native vegetation is alpine timothy, Nebraska sedge, and willows.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  High mountain valleys of north-central Colorado.  This series is of small extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Last updated by the state 10/73.
The superactive cation exchange activity class was added in 03/2003 to the taxonomic classification by the National Soil Survey Center on request of the Lakewood MLRA office, without review of the soil series property data. The remainder of this document has not been updated.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
